message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Multiple Mobile Robot Task and Motion Planning: A Survey
Paper Abstract: With recent advances in mobile robotics, autonomous systems, and artificial intelligence, there is a growing expectation that robots are able to solve complex problems. Many of these problems require multiple robots working cooperatively in a multi-robot system. Complex tasks may also include the interconnection of task-level specifications with robot motion-level constraints. Many recent works in the literature use multiple mobile robots to solve these complex tasks by integrating task and motion planning. We survey recent contributions to the field of combined task and motion planning for multiple mobile robots by categorizing works based on their underlying problem representations, and we identify possible directions for future research. We propose a taxonomy for task and motion planning based on system capabilities, applicable to multi-robot and single-robot systems.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here are the search results for "motion planning":

## Overview

Motion planning, also known as path planning or the navigation problem, is a computational problem to find a sequence of valid configurations that moves an object from the source to destination.

## Basic Problem

A basic motion planning problem is to compute a continuous path that connects a start configuration and a goal configuration, while avoiding collision with known obstacles.(no content)The robot and obstacle geometry is described in a 2D or 3D workspace, while the motion is represented as a path in configuration space.

## Applications

Motion planning has several robotics applications, such as autonomy, automation, and robot design in CAD software, as well as applications in other fields, such as animating digital characters, video games, architectural design, robotic surgery, and the study of biological molecules.

## Planning Approaches

Low-dimensional problems can be solved with grid-based algorithms or geometric algorithms, while sampling-based algorithms are currently considered state-of-the-art for motion planning in high-dimensional spaces.

For more detailed information, you can visit the Wikipedia article on [Motion planning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motion_planning).

Here are the search results for "motion planning":

## Overview

Motion planning, also known as path planning or the navigation problem, is a computational problem to find a sequence of valid configurations that moves an object from the source to destination.

## Basic Problem

A basic motion planning problem is to compute a continuous path that connects a start configuration and a goal configuration, while avoiding collision with known obstacles.(no content)The robot and obstacle geometry is described in a 2D or 3D workspace, while the motion is represented as a path in configuration space.

## Applications

Motion planning has several robotics applications, such as autonomy, automation, and robot design in CAD software, as well as applications in other fields, such as animating digital characters, video games, architectural design, robotic surgery, and the study of biological molecules.

## Planning Approaches

Low-dimensional problems can be solved with grid-based algorithms or geometric algorithms, while sampling-based algorithms are currently considered state-of-the-art for motion planning in high-dimensional spaces.

For more detailed information, you can visit the Wikipedia article on [Motion planning](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Motion_planning).

Here are the search results for "mobile robot":

## Overview

A mobile robot is an automatic machine that is capable of locomotion.(no content)Mobile robotics is usually considered to be a subfield of robotics and information engineering, and mobile robots have the capability to move around in their environment and are not fixed to one physical location.

## Components

The components of a mobile robot are a controller, sensors, actuators and power system.(no content)The controller is generally a microprocessor, embedded microcontroller or a personal computer (PC).

## Applications

Mobile robots have diverse applications across multiple sectors:

- **Healthcare and Warehouses**: Hospitals have been using autonomous mobile robots to move materials for many years, and warehouses have installed mobile robotic systems to efficiently move materials from stocking shelves to order fulfillment zones.
- **Other Settings**: Mobile robots are also found in industrial, military and security settings.

## Research Focus

Mobile robots are also a major focus of current research and almost every major university has one or more labs that focus on mobile robot research.

The search results also provide detailed information about specific mobile robot platforms, including the Khepera robot (developed at EPFL in Switzerland), industrial applications, and various research initiatives in the field of mobile robotics.

I've completed a web search for "task planning." Here's what I found:

## Overview

Task management is the process of overseeing a task through its lifecycle, involving planning, testing, tracking, and reporting.(no content)Task management can help individuals achieve goals or enable groups of individuals to collaborate and share knowledge for the accomplishment of collective goals.

## Key Approaches

**Project Planning**: Project planning is part of project management, which relates to the use of schedules such as Gantt charts to plan and subsequently report progress within the project environment, and can be done manually or by the use of project management software.

**Time Management**: Time management is the process of planning and exercising conscious control of time spent on specific activities—especially to increase effectiveness, efficiency and productivity.

**Work Breakdown Structure (WBS)**: WBS is a hierarchical and incremental decomposition of the project into deliverables and is a tree structure, which shows a subdivision of effort required to achieve an objective.

## Artificial Intelligence Planning

Automated planning and scheduling, sometimes denoted as simply AI planning, is a branch of artificial intelligence that concerns the realization of strategies or action sequences, typically for execution by intelligent agents, autonomous robots and unmanned vehicles.

Links: [{"title":"Annual Review of Control, Robotics, and Autonomous Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Annual_Review_of_Control,_Robotics,_and_Autonomous_Systems"},{"title":"Autonomous robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_robot"},{"title":"Autonomous system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_system"},{"title":"Institute of Robotics and Intelligent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Institute_of_Robotics_and_Intelligent_Systems"},{"title":"Built Robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Built_Robotics"},{"title":"Swarm robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_robotics"},{"title":"Robotic surgery - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot-assisted_surgery"},{"title":"Lethal autonomous weapon - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lethal_autonomous_weapon"},{"title":"Robot navigation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_navigation"},{"title":"Mobile robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_robot"}]

I've successfully performed a web search for "autonomous systems robotics". Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Overview

Autonomous robots are robots which can perform desired tasks in unstructured environments without continuous human guidance.

## Key Areas of Development

**Navigation and Localization:**
The most advanced systems now fuse information from various sensors for both localization (position) and navigation. Robot navigation means the robot's ability to determine its own position in its frame of reference and then to plan a path towards some goal location.

**Commercial Applications:**
Hospitals have been using autonomous mobile robots to move materials for many years, and warehouses have installed mobile robotic systems to efficiently move materials from stocking shelves to order fulfillment zones.

**Swarm Robotics:**
Swarm robotics is the study of how to design independent systems of robots without centralized control, with emerging swarming behavior created through the interactions between individual robots and the environment.

## Current Challenges

Autonomous robots remain highly vulnerable to unexpected changes in real-world environments, as even minor variations like a sudden beam of sunlight disrupting vision systems or unanticipated terrain irregularities can cause entire systems to fail.

The search results reveal that autonomous systems robotics is an active and rapidly evolving field with applications spanning healthcare, warehousing, security, construction, and military domains.

Hospitals have been using autonomous mobile robots to move materials for many years, and warehouses have installed mobile robotic systems to efficiently move materials from stocking shelves to order fulfillment zones.

**Swarm Robotics:**
Swarm robotics is the study of how to design independent systems of robots without centralized control, with emerging swarming behavior created through the interactions between individual robots and the environment.

## Current Challenges

Autonomous robots remain highly vulnerable to unexpected changes in real-world environments, as even minor variations like a sudden beam of sunlight disrupting vision systems or unanticipated terrain irregularities can cause entire systems to fail.

The search results reveal that autonomous systems robotics is an active and rapidly evolving field with applications spanning healthcare, warehousing, security, construction, and military domains.

I've found comprehensive information about multi-robot systems. Here are the key findings:

## Overview

A multi-agent system (MAS or "self-organized system") is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

## Swarm Robotics

One important approach is swarm robotics. Swarm robotics is the study of how to design independent systems of robots without centralized control. The emerging swarming behavior of robotic swarms is created through the interactions between individual robots and the environment.(no content)The design of swarm robotics systems is guided by swarm intelligence principles, which promote fault tolerance, scalability, and flexibility.

## Key Characteristics

The agents in a multi-agent system have several important characteristics: Autonomy (agents are at least partially independent, self-aware, autonomous) and Decentralization (no agent is designated as controlling).

## Applications

The main goal is to control a large number of robots (with limited sensing/processing ability) to accomplish a common task/problem.(no content)Progress has been made in the application of autonomous swarms in the field of manufacturing, known as swarm 3D printing. This is particularly useful for the production of large structures and components, where traditional 3D printing is not able to be utilized due to hardware size constraints.

I've completed the web search for "artificial intelligence." Here's an overview of what I found:

## Definition and Core Concepts

Artificial intelligence (AI) is the capability of computational systems to perform tasks typically associated with human intelligence, such as learning, reasoning, problem-solving, perception, and decision-making.(no content)Artificial intelligence was founded as an academic discipline in 1956, and has since evolved into a diverse field with many applications.

## Types of AI

The field includes different levels of AI capability:
- Artificial general intelligence (AGI)—sometimes called human‑level intelligence AI—is a type of artificial intelligence that would match or surpass human capabilities across virtually all cognitive tasks.
- Generative artificial intelligence (Generative AI, or GenAI) is a subfield of artificial intelligence that uses generative models to generate text, images, videos, audio, software code or other forms of data.

## Applications

AI is being applied across numerous domains, including:
- Astronomy to analyze increasing amounts of available data and applications, mainly for "classification, regression, clustering, forecasting, generation, discovery, and the development of new scientific insights." For example, it is used for discovering exoplanets, forecasting solar activity, and distinguishing between signals and instrumental effects in gravitational wave astronomy.
- Contact centers and writing tasks, with studies finding generative AI increased productivity by 15% in contact centers and up to 40% in writing tasks.

## Current Challenges

Key challenges include ethics, transparency, and energy consumption. Power demand for data centers and AI might double by 2026, with additional electric power usage equal to electricity used by the whole Japanese nation. Prodigious power consumption by AI is responsible for the growth of fossil fuel use, and might delay closings of obsolete, carbon-emitting coal energy facilities.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Perfect! I've successfully completed the analysis of the survey paper on mobile robot task and motion planning. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Type:** Survey - This paper explicitly reviews and categorizes existing work in combined task and motion planning for multiple mobile robots, rather than proposing new methods.

**Extracted Triples (6 total):**

1. **Mobile robot** (concept) - The core subject of the survey, representing autonomous systems that can move and operate in various environments.

2. **Autonomous robot** (concept) - Central to the paper's focus on systems that perform complex tasks without continuous human guidance.

3. **Artificial intelligence** (concept) - AI techniques are fundamental to enabling mobile robots to solve complex problems and make autonomous decisions.

4. **Multi-agent system** (concept) - Provides the theoretical foundation for coordinating multiple mobile robots to work cooperatively.

5. **Motion planning** (method) - A core method for determining robot paths and movements while avoiding obstacles.

6. **Automated planning and scheduling** (method) - Provides the task-level reasoning and action sequencing for accomplishing complex robot objectives.

All triples have been validated successfully with proper Wikipedia URLs and comprehensive relevance descriptions. The validation confirms that all required fields are present and correctly formatted.
